In what respect were they dressed like these two men? - They were dressed in white frocks; they had flapped their hats over their faces.

RICHARD BURR
sworn.
I was one of these officers; I was knocked down by the side of Mr. Bacon; I heard the last witness, every word that he said all came under my knowledge.
You know none of the prisoners? - No.

SAMUEL WHITING
sworn.

Did you know
Joseph Pierson
? - No.
Do you remember the time in April last when the officers were beat in the night? - Yes.
Was you at Deptford at that time? - Yes.
Who with? - Along with those people that beat him.

Name them. - There was one Gypsey George, who is not taken,
Edward George
,
Thomas Henman
,
Robert Harley
, and
Benjamin Harley
.

What time was this you are speaking of? - About the hour of three in the morning.
Edward George
came to my house by the Tide-mill, and left word for me to go down to the King's Head; I went thither about eleven o'clock, where I saw Gypsey George,
Edward George
,
Benjamin Harley
,
Thomas Henman
, and
Robert Harley
, and some whom I did not know; there was one Long George, a butcher, there; they said to me, you are come too late; we have just emptied the bottle of gin, or you might have had some.

Who keeps the King's Head? - I do not know his name. Gypsey George fetched another bottle of gin; they drank that; they staid an hour, I believe, and then went out; they went up Church-street, searching all the places after these officers; they staid about the Broadway some time; then Gypsey George said, we shall not meet with them to-night; come home, and I will give you some gin, and then we will part and go to bed; in the mean time two men knocked at Gypsey George's door, Gypsey George opened the door, and let them in; they said they wanted some money; they all had a glass of gin a-piece, and they set off to seek these custom-house officers.

How many might there be in the whole? - I believe ten in the whole; they went immediately over the bridge, where, they said, the officers were gone; then they divided into two parties, one went towards Blackheath, the other towards Greenwich; soon after, those that went towards Greenwich came back, and waited till the other party came to them; then they came all together over Deptford-bridge, and went down Church-street; two men that had staid behind, came up and said, they saw the officers run to the butcher's shambles just over against where the watchman stood.

Can you tell their names? - No; Gypsey George said, There are enough of us now to go and lick them; Gypsey George came up the street to where the officers were, by three elm-trees, and the other party followed; as soon as Gypsey George came up to the elm-trees, he made a loud alarm, and immediately knocked one man down with his stick.

Who was there at that time? - All of them; we lost them all for that time; we heard an alarm of them in Church-street; we ran down after them; then I saw Gypsey George take down Hughes's Field; when he came down to the bottom of Hughes's Field, he seized Pierson by the collar, and said, if he did not tell his name, he would cut his throat.
Who were with him? - The prisoner and myself; Gypsey George knocked Pierson down, and the other three came up and beat Pierson as he lay upon the ground.

Name their names? -
Robert Harley
,
Benjamin Harley
, and
Edward George
; they beat him, I suppose, for very near a quarter of an hour.

Did he say any thing? - Gypsey George said, D - n his eyes, if you kill a dozen of them, there is no sin in it. Pierson begged for mercy; he begged of them not to beat him any more, for he said he had a wife and four small children.

Are you sure
Benjamin Harley
and
Thomas Henman
were there at that time? - I am; they went away from him about forty yards; then Gypsey George said, D - n his eyes, he has not got enough, let us go back and beat him more; Gypsey George went back and hit him several violent blows.
What did Henman do? - He said nothing.
Did Pierson say any thing more? - He cried and groaned; Gypsey George said, Come up, my men, and hit him a blow a-piece for me.

Were any more blows given by any body? - They struck him again after Gypsey George had been back and given him these violent blows, they accordingly did give him a blow a-piece:
Edward Johnson
and
Thomas Henman
hit him two blows over the head.

Were any other blows given by any body else? - No; Pierson begged for mercy, Benjamin and
Robert Harley
did, then we all came up into the Broadway; Butcher George came up, Gypsey George said to him, D - n your eyes, go down to town and pick up the dead.

Had you met any body before this? - We met two people who were going home,
James Greenrod
and
John Rolfe
.
What passed when you met those two men? - Only those words; they went back home with them to have a dram; Gypsey George asked them to go home with him.
Gypsey George knew them? - Yes; they are neighbours.
Where is Gypsey George's house? - In Mill-lane, Deptford, just by there.
Did all the company go to George's house in Mill-lane? - Yes; and these two men.
You drank gin there? - Yes.

What was said then? - After they had drank the gin, George said, I have picked up one of their hats, I do not know whose it was: he gave half a crown to
Robert Harley
,
Benjamin Harley
,
Edward Jones
, and myself; he gave three shillings to
Thomas Henman
.

Was the expression go down and pick up the dead before or after the money was given? - Before; it was before we went into George's house; it was almost directly after we met these two men, before George asked them to go to his house.
How came he to give three shillings to Henman, and half a crown to the rest? - I cannot say; he did not give any reason.
From HARLEY. Whether you did not say that I was innocent, that you swore to me because you could not find out Gypsey George and the rest? - I never said that.
HARLEY. He said he swore against us to save himself. - I never said any such thing to any body.

HENMAN. He said, last Friday morning, at the cage, before three or four people, that we were as innocent of it as a child, only he swore to us because he could not find Gypsey George. - I never said any such thing.

Counsel for the Crown. Was you taken into custody, or did you voluntarily surrender yourself? - I fetched the officer out of the church as soon as I heard the party was dead, and surrendered myself up immediately.

JOHN DICEY
sworn.
I am a waterman, and live at Deptford.

Do you remember hearing any noise near your house on the 11th of April? - Yes; I was lying in bed; I heard a great hallooing, and a noise in the street; presently I heard them driving a man about, and could hear them beat him; the man ran by my house, and all the people, and at last I heard them making this noise ten or twelve minutes, I believe, before I got out of bed, and just about twenty or thirty yards from my house they had knocked this man down: I heard the poor man begging for his life.

Who was that poor man? -
Joseph Pierson
; when I heard this man say, Pray, gentlemen, spare my life, I could lie in my bed no longer, but I ran down, opened the door, and ran up to the man's assistance as near as I could go, and they ran away and left the man; but who they were I do not know.
How many might there be? - There might be four or five, or three or four, I cannot justly say.

When you came up to the man, did you know who it was? - Not till I asked him. I found him lying upon his back, with his head and shoulders up agains t one Mr. Savage, a custom-house officer's gate, who was talking to him out of the window; he was most terribly beat, and all over blood: one Mr. Mitchel, a publican, came to my assistance, and one
John Wright
, and they got him up; I ran in doors, and got a candle, and took him into my house, and then I sent this
John Wright
for a surgeon; the surgeon refused to come because he was at my house; I went and called up Mr. Dickerson, a surveyor of the town, to get a surgeon.

Why would not the surgeon come to your house? - I do not know; I called up Mr. Dickerson, then we went to the same surgeon, and he came to my house; before that I went out into the street with a candle to seek for Pierson's Pistol, as he said he had dropped his Pistol; I found it, and brought it to him: it was charged, but there was no flint in it.

Did you know any of the people? - I could not swear to one of them; Mr. Dickerson asked him how he could be beat in such a barbarous manner without discharging of his pistol, he made answer, he was loth to take life, though they took his.

BARBARA DUDLEY
sworn.

I live in Hughes's Fields; I heard the noise in the night of the 11th of April, it waked me out of my sleep: I got up and went to my chamber-window; I heard a person desperately beating a poor man, he cried out terribly now and then, O you will kill me, I have enough, I have enough, do not beat me any more, I have enough; while I was looking, I heard five or six men run by, but I cannot tell who they were; they ran towards the man that was beating.

Was it one, two, or more? - I heard the blows, I cannot say how many were beating him; just as the men came opposite to me, one said to the other, D - n you, come along, you cannot run; when they came lower, this person that was striking the poor man said, Now, my lads, give him every one a blow for me, and that will do for him; after that every one that ran down took a stroke as near as I could tell the strokes; he cried out terribly, the groans would pierce any one's heart to hear them, O you'll kill me, I have enough, I have enough; I saw the same number come back by my window; I went down, and my next-door neighbour said, are you not ashamed of yourselves, you murdering villains? They d - d her eyes, and bid her get in, or they would break her windows, for she had no business with them.

JAMES GREENROD
sworn.
I am a coal-porter, and live near the Tide-mill at Deptford.
Do you remember when the misfortune happened to the poor man Pierson? - Yes.

Who was with you? -
John Rolfe
; it was between three and four in the morning; we had been to the lime-kilns, and were going home, we met Gypsey George,
Robert Harley
,
Benjamin Harley
,
Samuel Whiting
,
Edward George
, and
Thomas Henman
, they had all sticks in their hands; they asked us where we had been, we told them we were just going home, that we had been to get some gin in the Broadway, but no one was up; Gypsey George said, if we would go back with him, he would give us some gin.

You knew him before? - I knew them all before; we all went together to Gypsey George's lodgings in Mill-lane, we had two glasses of gin a-piece there; when we went in, after Gypsey George had given us the gin, he gave the two Harleys,
Edward George
, and
Samuel Whiting
and Henman, money, he gave four of them half a crown each, and one three shillings; I believe it was to Henman that he gave three shillings, but I am not sure.
Did he say what he gave that for? - He did not mention that.
What did he say after that? - We had another glass of gin a-piece, and then we parted; he said, Go down the town and pick up the dead.
Who did he say that to? - To all of them.

JOHN ROLFE
sworn.
Do you remember being at Deptford when Pierson was so beat? - Yes; I was with Greenrod.
When was it? - Upon Friday morning at between three and four o'clock we met them at the Tide-mill.

Is that near Hughes's Fields? - No; about half a mile off, we met Gypsey George, the two Harleys,
Samuel Whiting
, and Henman. I have been a neighbour to them for ten or twelve years; Gypsey George asked where we had been, we said into the Broadway to get some gin, but there was not any body up; he said come along with me, and I will give you some gin; we went back again with them to Gypsey George's house in Mill-lane; he locked the door when we were in, and he gave each of the company a glass of gin a-piece, then he went up stairs for some silver, and gave them half a crown a-piece, except one, who had three shillings; after he had paid the money, he gave us another glass of gin, and then he said, Go down the town and pick up the dead.

Mr.
JOHN FRANKS
sworn.
I am a surgeon, and live at Deptford.

Do you remember being sent for to this Pierson? - I was; it was three or four o'clock in the morning when the accident happened; I was sent for to one
John Dyson
's house in Hughes's Fields; there I saw Pierson, he had four terrible large wounds in his head; I dressed him, and ordered him to the hospital.
Were there any other wounds about him? - I did not examine any other parts; he complained he was bruised much in his hands and legs.
And did not you examine him? - No.

Mr.
GEORGE NEAL
sworn.
I am a surgeon at the London-hospital.

I believe you attended this poor man? - Yes; he had three or four very dreadful wounds upon his head; he was very badly bruised upon his breast, in short there was not a free place but what was beat and bruised in a very bad manner, even so that I asked leave of the governor to suffer his wife to be with him; she was with him all the while he was there; he was so bruised that he could not stir himself the least in the world; his head, the os frontis, the forehead was laid bare, the occipitis was cut, his breast was dreadful, his right arm was so bruised that we laid it open; there was a large extravasation of blood daily.
How long did he live in the hospital? - About a month.
Did he die of these wounds? - Certainly; I begged leave that the poor woman, his wife, might be indulged in staying with him, and she did not leave him the whole time.
Did he give any account how he came by those bruises or wounds? - I never asked him about that; there was a deposition taken by two magistrates.
He was in his senses? - Yes, always.

JOHN SHERWOOD
, Esq. sworn.
This is the information (producing it) that I took from the deceased in the London-hospital; he was in his perfect senses at the time he gave it.
The Information read.

Signed the mark of
Joseph Pierson
, sworn at the London-hospital before us
John Sherwood
and
William Blackmore
.
Middlesex, to wit.
"The information of

"
Joseph Pierson
, officer of his Majesty's " customs, taken before us
John Sherwood

"and
William Blackmore
, Esquires, two of
"his Majesty's justices of peace for the said
"country, at the London-hospital, 20th of
"April 1776, who on his oath says, That on
"Thursday evening the eleventh instant he

"this deponent,
Richard Burr
,
William Bacon
,

"and
William Anchor
, having an information
"of a large quantity of run goods,
"went as their duty, with an intent to seize
"the said goods, at about one o'clock the
"next morning; when two men came through
"the turnpike leading to Blackheath, and
"when they saw us gave three whistles, and
"in about twenty minutes there came to near
"the number of twenty men, armed with
"sticks and bludgeons, and attacked this deponent
"with the other officers above-mentioned,
"without any provocation whatever,
"and violently bruised, beat, and wounded
"this deponent, crying out at the same time,
"let us every one have another blow at him
"for liberty; and this deponent says, he doth
"not know the names of any of the rioters
"aforesaid; and that he now languishes, and
"his life in the utmost danger in consequence
"of the assault aforesaid."
HARLEY's DEFENCE.
I was at home and abed at twelve o'clock that night; I never went a smuggling or was in company with a smuggler half an hour in my life.
HENMAN's DEFENCE.
I was at home in the morning between one and two o'clock; I have witnesses here to prove that.
Court. I don't call upon Bland to make his defence, because there is no evidence to affect him.
FOR HARLEY.

AMELIA TOAM
sworn.
I live at Deptford.
Do you follow any business? - No otherwise than go out to needle work at times.
Are you married or single? - Single.

What have you to say for
Benjamin Harley
? - I was at the house where he lived; he happened to be out; the landlady sent me to see after him as he staid out later than usual; it was of a Thursday night about six weeks ago; I went to see after him and met him in the Broadway coming home, that was between ten and eleven o'clock; I took hold of his arm, he said he was going to see after a barge of bricks and dung; the bricks were not come up, and he came home directly; he was to go to heave them out of the barge the next day; I live in the same house with him; when we came to the door the people were gone to bed; we called to the landlord, he said it was a late hour to come home; Harley said it is but just eleven o'clock; the landlord made answer that the bell had just rang at half after eleven; the landlord came down with the key in his hand and let him in.
You are sure it was a Thursday night? - Yes.
Do you know the time when Pierson was killed at Deptford? - I cannot tell any thing about that.
Cross Examination.
So you don't know the time when Pierson was killed? - He was killed by all account on the Friday morning, as he was out on Thursday night.

When was you first desired to remember the time? - I never heard of it till he was taken up the last week; I heard the gentleman was dead, but I don't think Harley was guilty of the crime; if he was he might have got off.
When did you first hear of Pierson's death? - Last Friday was a week.
You heard of his being beat before? - I heard of a gentleman's being beat.
But you did not hear of Harley's being accused? - No.

But how came you to remember that this was that night before this gentleman was beat? - I don't remember any more than what the people said that he was beat the night before that morning; we heard of the gentleman being hurt on the Friday morning.

You did not hear that it concerned Harley? - No; I saw
Samuel Whiting
clap his hand upon an iron bar, and he said,
Benjamin Harley
is as innocent as these iron bars; that was this day week.
Where was Whiting? - He was in the same cage; he said Harley has no call to be afraid, he is as innocent as these iron bars.

Did not you understand at that time that Whiting had surrendered himself of his own accord and had accused
Benjamin Harley
? - He had so.
Then he told you, that what he had said before was false? - Yes.

ROBERT GEORGE
sworn.

Are you any relation of the man that they call
Edward George
, or Gipsey George? - I am brother to
Edward George
; I heard this Whiting say that
Benjamin Harley
was as innocent as the iron bars; this was on last Friday morning.

Was it before or after that he went to the justice of peace? - Before; I was outside, Whiting and
Benjamin Harley
were within.

ANN HATTON
sworn.
I know Mr. Harley to be a very sober honest man, as far as I know, in all respects.

Do you remember the time when Pierson was killed at Deptford? - No, only the talk of the neighbourhood that he was killed upon a Thursday night; Harley was at home by twelve o'clock that night that it was thought this man was killed; I came down myself to let him in.
Was it before or after twelve? - The clock struck twelve as I was getting into bed after I had let him in.
How long was that after he came in? - A very short time; I went up to bed directly.
Do you know what day of the month it was? - No, it was in the Easter holidays.

Who came home with him? - This girl,
Amelia Harley
.
What is she this man's wife? - No.
Does she go by his name? - No.
Why did you call her Harley? - I meant Toam; I mentioned the name Harley by mistake, having been speaking about Harley.
What are you? - I work in a garden; my husband drives a team.
What was done with the key of the house after you let this man and the girl in? - I locked the door and took the key up with me as usual.
Can the door be opened inside without the key? - No.
You don't know of his being out that night after that? - No.

THOMAS OVERTON
sworn.

I heard
Samuel Whiting
mention that they were both innocent, and Gipsey George was the man that committed the crime; he said that in Deptford cage between five and six in the morning; he said Gipsey George was the man that hit the last blow.
What are you? - A labouring man; I work in the brick fields in summer, and sometimes work for him in the winter.

WILLIAM HARLEY
sworn.

What relation are you to the prisoner? - Brother to him; I went to the evidence in Clerkenwell-bridewell, and asked him the whole of the affair; he told me last Tuesday that the principal man that was concerned in the affair was Gipsey George; that Gipsey George, one Butcher George, and one
Ned George
, that after they had beat him and come away, that these three went back again and beat him after the rest had left beating him.

Who did he mean by after the rest had beat him? - He said that both Bob and
Benjamin Harley
cried for mercy upon him.
Then he was there? - I don't know that he was there.
He could not cry for mercy if he was not there? - Whiting told me that he said before justice Sherwood that Harley was innocent.

Court. Mr. Sherwood, this man says that Whiting said he had said before you, that
Benjamin Harley
was innocent.
Mr. SHERWOOD. Whiting positively declared that Henman and Harley were the men, but that Bland was innocent.
FOR HENMAN.

HANNAH CAMPBELL
sworn.
I live in Church-street, Deptford.
What business do you follow? - Nothing but my hard labour.
Do you let lodgings? - Yes.

Have you any thing to say for
Thomas Henman
? - I have nothing to say; he came in a quarter before two as near as I can guess; my little girl let him in.
What night was this? - The Thursday night about six weeks ago.
Do you know the time that Pierson was beat? - I heard of it the next morning.

How came you to say as near as you can guess about two? - I heard the clock strike soon after he came in; I was between sleep and awake; I told but two, whether it had struck before or not I cannot tell. Whiting told them it was not worth while to make themselves unhappy, that they would both be back again at night, and not to make themselves uneasy; that was the next morning after they were taken; they were handcuffed together.
Who were they? - Henman and Harley.
Did he say he was innocent himself? - No, he did not say any thing about it.

SARAH FRENCH
sworn.

I was at the cage window pouring him out some beer:
Samuel Whiting
fell a crying, I asked him what he was crying for? he said, never mind it, lads, God Almighty will send you out of your trouble, your are both innocent.
When was this? - Last Friday morning.
Cross Examination.
They were all three in the cage together at that time? - Yes.

ELIZABETH RICHARDS
sworn.
When he came up with the prisoners, he came to take leave of us; Whiting made answer, never mind, my girl, he will come up again to night; they are both innocent.
Cross Examination.
Where did he say this? - At Mr. Campbell's house.
They were all three handcuffed together? - Yes.

CHRISTIAN WILSON
sworn.
The men were handcuffed going out of the house; I was following them, Whiting said, don't make yourself uneasy, they will be cleared, and be back at night.

BLAND
NOT GUILTY .

HARLEY
GUILTY .
Death .

HENMAN
GUILTY .
Death .
They received sentence immediately (this being Friday) to be hanged at Tyburn the Monday following, and their bodies to be afterwards dissected and anatomized; which sentence was executed upon them .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice ASTON.

465.
JOHN MAYO
was indicted for that
he in the king's highway, in and upon
James Jay
did make an assault, putting him in corporal fear and danger of his life, and stealing from his person a pair of metal buckles, value two shillings, a metal watch, value forty shillings, three guineas, and twenty-six shillings in money numbered, the property of the said James , April 27th .

JAMES JAY
sworn.

I was robbed at Bayswater
on the 24th of April, at about eight in the evening, by the prisoner at the bar of my watch, three guineas, twenty-six shillings, a pair of buckles, and a pocket handkerchief, which is not mentioned, I believe, in the indictment; the watch case was metal gilt, and a gilt chain.

Was there any person with you at the time you was robbed? - I was by myself on foot; there was another person in company with the prisoner; I should know that person if I was to see him; I understand he answers to the name of Richardson.
Have you recovered any of the things again? - No, none of them.
Have you ever seen them at any time since? - No, never; I heard that my watch had been sold to a Jew with a watch of Captain Young's who has been robbed.
When did you see the prisoner after the robbery? - I believe that day week at Sir John Fielding's.

When did you first receive any intelligence about the prisoner? - On the Wednesday after the robbery, I took the first coach on the stand, and went and gave information at Sir
John Fielding
's, and left a direction where I was to be found, and, on the Wednesday following, Sir John sent for me, and ordered me to be there by eleven o'clock; I went and found the prisoner in custody; I attended the examination.
What passed at the examination? - I believe the prisoner was not asked any questions.

Did you at any time swear to the prisoner? - I did; when I went in to Sir
John Fielding
's, the prisoners were brought in, and I immediately knew the prisoner at the bar to be the person that had robbed me.

Can you positively take upon you to say that the prisoner is the identical person that robbed you? - The prisoner is the person that put both his hands in my breeches-pocket, while the other held me; I observed them look at me before I came up to them, which drew my attention to them; they came up to me, and the other struck me up against the bank, and said, D - n your eyes, your life or your money.

Did the prisoner say any thing to you at the time they robbed you? - I don't recollect that he said any thing; after they had taken my money, they stooped for my buckles; I said, Gentlemen, don't use me ill, my buckles are of no value: Richardson said, B - st your eyes, if you say a word I'll blow your brains out; after they had taken my buckles, the person who is not taken, took me by the shoulder, and Richardson struck me on the side of the face with a stick, and said, D - n your eyes, you shall not look this way, look towards London: there was a post-cha ise coming, I heard it near at hand; they left me directly, I turned again, and went to my friend at the sign of the Crown, and told him I had been robbed; I had not left the house above five minutes: the prisoner took the buckles out of my shoes, and some keys out of my pocket, which they put in again. Here is a person in court they offered my watch to that evening.
How do you know it was your watch; did you see it? - No.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I know nothing at all of the robbery.

GUILTY .
Death .

Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron PERRYN
.
See No. 444 in the preceding number.

466.
JOHN BLACKWELL
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Stratton
, on the 30th of April , about the hour of ten in the forenoon, and stealing a brass barrel pistol, mounted with brass, value ten shillings, the property of
Thomas Stratton
; four linen shirts, value eight shillings, and three linen handkerchiefs, value three shillings, the property of
George Turner
, in the same dwelling-house .

ROBERT WALKER
sworn.
[The pistol was produced in court, and the witness deposed that it was Mr. Stratton's property.]

GEORGE TURNER
sworn.
I am coachman to Mr. Stratton; I lodge in the room over the coach-house; the things belonging to me were in my box, locked up; on the 30th of April the box was broke open.
[The box was produced in court, and deposed to by Turner.]
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I leave it to the good gentlemen of the jury; I have no witnesses.
NOT GUILTY of breaking and entering the dwelling-house, but GUILTY of stealing the goods .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

467.
WILLIAM DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing eight guineas, and a half guinea, the property of
Nicholas Gotts
, in the dwelling-house of
Francis Morris
, April the 27th .
The prosecutor was called, but not appearing, the court ordered his recognizance to be estreated.
NOT GUILTY .

468.
WILLIAM BRANDFORD
was indicted for
stealing two pair of mens leather shoes, value two shillings, and 360 half-pence, the property of
James Finch
; a three pint glass bottle, value six-pence, a pint of brandy, value one shilling, a tin canister, value four-pence, a pound weight of green tea, value eight shillings, a pair of half leather boots, value three shillings, and two pair of mens leather shoes, value two shillings , the property of
William Kitchiner
, March the 18th .
"None of the things mentioned in the indictment
"were found, but the bottle
"and canister, in the lodging of the prisoner,
"which the prosecutor could not undertake
"to swear to, and there was no other evidence " to bring the charge home to the prisoner."
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

469.
WILLIAM NICHOLSON
was indicted for
stealing a silver watch, value forty shillings, a steel chain, value six-pence, a steel watch key, value one penny, and another steel key, value one penny , the property of
William Tandy
, May the 9th .
"The prisoner was the brother in-law of
"the prosecutor; the only evidence against
"him was a confession that he took the watch,
"but meant to return it, and it appeared his
"brother had often let him wear it.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

470.
FRANCES the wife of ELIAS BARLOW
was indicted for
stealing three linen curtains, value six-pence, a linen sheet, value two shillings and six-pence, two copper saucepans, value two shillings, a feather bolster, value eighteen pence, a copper stewpan, value one shilling, and two flat irons, value one shilling, the property of
Jacob Otto
, being in a ready furnished lodging, let by the said Jacob by contract to the said Frances, against the statute , May the 5th .

MARY OTTO
sworn.

I am the wife of
Jacob Otto
; I let a ready furnished room, up three pair of stairs, to the prisoner, at half a crown a week; the things mentioned in the indictment were in the lodging; I went into the room and missed the things; I asked her what she had done with them; she said she had pawned them; I have recovered several of them.

[
Robert Arlz
, a pawnbroker, produced the curtains and sheet, which had been pawned with him by the prisoner, and they were deposed to by the prosecutor.]
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I pawned them with an intent to fetch them out again, but my landlady took me to the watch-house and would not let me.
GUILTY .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

471.
GEORGE GRACE
was indicted for
stealing a guinea the property of
John Staneford
, May the 10th .
"It appeared upon the evidence that the
"prisoner changed half a guinea with the prosecutor,
"and had the guinea given him thro'
"mistake among the silver."
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

472.
HENRY JORDAN
was indicted for
feloniously being found at large before the expiration of the term for which he had been ordered to be transported , April the 6th .

The Record of the prisoner's conviction for a capital felony was produced and read, and also his majesty's pardon on condition of transportation for fourteen years, which had been accepted of by the prisoner.

PERCIVAL PHILLIPS
sworn.

I am a constable; I belong to Sir
John Fielding
; I know the prisoner; he was tried for a highway robbery upon Mr. Hoare; I apprehended him; I am sure he is the man.

MATTHEW RICHMOND
sworn.
I produced the watch when the prisoner was tried; I am sure he is the man that was tried for robbing Mr. Hoare.

JONATHAN BUTTERWORTH
sworn.

I had a letter from Sir
John Fielding
, informing me that the prisoner had made his escape, and ordering me to make diligent search after him; I took him the next day at Manchester, making a woman's shoe.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

When I came from on board of ship, I did it for fear of my life; there were twelve of us upon deck, and one Smith threatened to cut every one's throat that would not go into the boat, and come on shore. I went down to Manchester to follow my business.

GUILTY .
DEATH .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

473.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing a watch, with an inside case made of silver and gilt with gold, and an outside shagreen case, value forty-five shillings, a steel watch-chain, value two shillings, a chrystal stone set in gold, value twenty shillings, the property of
William Mitchel
, in the dwelling-house of the said William , April the 20th .

ELIZABETH MITCHEL
sworn.

I am the wife of
William Mitchel
, who is a serjeant in the guards , and lives in Petty-France
; upon Saturday was month I went out about four o'clock; I shut my door, and locked it, I left no one in the house; I came home about six o'clock, and found the door open, the lock was bent, and the staple broke in the middle; when I went up stairs I missed my watch, which used to hang by the fire-place.
[The watch was produced in court, and deposed to by the prosecutrix.]

ROBERT MINNS
sworn.

I am a pawnbroker in Petty-France; the prisoner at the bar and one Scandal, who stands here, came to my shop on Monday the 22d of April, about seven in the morning; Scandal produced the watch, but the prisoner said the watch was his property; I opened the watch, and asked a good many questions about it; I found it was not his own, for he said he did not know whether it was gold or no; I had received an information of a watch being lost; I stepped with the watch to Mrs. Mitchel, she owned the watch; when I came back again, these two men were standing in the street; they were taken up and carried before a magistrate. Scandal asked if I would lend a guinea upon it, for that the prisoner had pledged it before, and had taken it out and brought it, but they did not know what was the value of it.

THOMAS WATSON
sworn.

On Saturday this Brown, the prisoner, came by the door where I was, a dust-man informed me he had a seal to sell; Brown brought the seal to me, and asked me to buy it; I said I did not want to buy it; I asked what he would take for it, he said a shilling, I gave him six-pence; I did not know what it was worth.
[The seal was produced in court, and deposed to by the prosecutrix.]
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I found the seal in the Broadway, Westminster.
GUILTY of stealing to the value of thirty-nine shillings .
Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice ASTON.

474.
JOHN STORER
was indicted for
that he, on the 27th of April , feloniously, wilfully, and maliciously did mix and mingle and make up into a certain horse-ball, a quantity of arsenic with divers other ingredients, and afterwards on the same day feloniously did give and administer the same unto a certain bay horse of the price of 20 l. the property of
Samuel Whitbread
, Esq ; and did force the same down into the body of the said horse, whereby the said horse became variously ill and distempered in his body, of which he languished unto the 29th day of the same month and then died, and so the Jurors say that the said
John Storer
did kill, poison, and destroy the said horse, against the statute, &c .

2d Count. That he one bay horse of the price of 20 l. the property of
Samuel Whitbread
, in the stable of the said Samuel, wilfully, maliciously, and feloniously did kill and destroy, against the statute.
The witnesses were examined apart at the request of the prisoner.

JACOB YELLOWLEY
sworn.

I am clerk to Mr. Whitbread: last winter at the time of the severe frost, when the street was very slippery, Mr. Whitbread had a horse lamed; this horse was put under the care of
John Edwards
, Mr. Whitbread's farrier, for cure; he was under his hands for a considerable time and grew worse, and Edwards said he could do no more; one Mr. Buckle then had him under his care, and the horse grew better; Buckle, however, was discharged; the horse was again put under Edwards's care, and again grew worse; he was put again under the care of Buckle, and grew better, so that he was ordered to have light shoes put on, and to be put out to grass, thinking that exercise might do him good: I saw the horse on the Saturday, he seemed better of his lameness, but I observed he looked sickly, dull, and heavy about the eyes; on Monday morning I heard the horse was dead; that he died in great agitation of body; on the death of the horse Buckle was sent for; he told me the horse was certainly poisoned; I desired some people might go with him and see the horse opened; they returned with some stuff which they took out of the body of the horse; I did not see it taken out. I made Mr. Whitbread acquainted with the whole matter, and he ordered a warrant to be got and Storer taken up; he worked in Edwards's shop, which is in Mr. Whitbread's yard; I think I saw him at work in the shop on Saturday evening, but I cannot be positive.
Cross Examination.

Was not Edwards taken up on this affair? - Yes, he was; we did not know who to suspect; the suspicion lay mostly on Storer: the business is done in the yard, but the horse that was poisoned did not stand in the yard, but in a stable on the other side of the street.

WILLIAM SCOTT
sworn.

I work with Mr. Edwards in Golden-lane: I heard
John Storer
ask Blanden, in Mr. Whitbread's shop, What is the strongest poison for a horse? I believe it was on a Saturday in the last month; I worked but two days, Friday and Saturday; Blanden said, I cannot tell, I had like to have poisoned myself once by taking mercury; I said, if he had taken arsenic instead of mercury, it would have poisoned him or a horse either, for it was stronger than a caustic: afterwards, about nine in the morning, he asked me to go and fetch him two ounces of yellow arsenic, and he would pay me again what it cost; I went to the chymist's at Barbican, he refused to sell it me; I shewed him my apron, and said I was a farrior, and we used it as a medicine for horses; he went and asked advice, and then came and served me; I pounded it in a ladle and put it in a drawer; I said to the prisoner, Jack, there it is: he said it was very well; I never saw what came of it.
Cross Examination.
Did he say his master had ordered him to get it for any horse? - No, he was foreman of the shop; he said nothing about his master to me.

ROBERT BARNES
sworn.

I am shopman to Messrs. Clark and Jacomb, chymists in Barbican: upon the 26th or 27th of April, to the best of my remembrance, Scott came to our shop for two ounces of arsenic; I asked what it was for, as it was a thing we did not sell to any body but farriers and refiners; he said it was for a farrier; he shewed me his apron, and told me he knew how to use it; I heard no more of it till the Tuesday or Wednesday following, when his master, Mr. Edwards, came to me to know if I had served such a person with arsenic.

JOHN BLANDEN
sworn.

I work with
John Edwards
, a farrier, in Golden-lane; I worked at Mr. Whitbread's shop a fortnight or better, I cannot say the time: on the Friday before the horse died the prisoner and I were working together; he said to me, John, do you know what will poison a horse? I said, no, I cannot tell what will poison a horse, I had like to have poisoned myself once by taking mercury; Scott made answer, if I had taken arsenic instead of mercury it would have poisoned me or a horse either; soon after he asked Scott if he would buy him some arsenic: Scott said, if he wanted any he would. On the Saturday afternoon a horse was brought to have a shoe put on; I put it on; I had not nails enough, I went into the shop to point some nails, and saw the prisoner with a ladle before him on the forge; there was nobody at all in the shop; in the ladle there seemed to me to be a ball such as we give to horses that have colds; out of the drawer near the forge he took a paper with brown or yellow powder, and mixed it up together and made a ball, and put the ball he had been mixing in the ladle into a piece of paper, and laid it down upon the vice-bench: I went out to finish putting the shoe on; when I had finished the horse, he told me to go into the stable and put two old shoes on that horse that was lame; I went over with him; he got into the stable; I saw him go up to the horse's head, he had the ball in his hand; I do not know where he took it from, it was the very same ball he had in the ladle; he gave it to the horse; the horse made no resistance at all; then I turned him round to put the shoes on him; I went into the stable and laid hold of the ladle he had made the ball in, it was very nasty; I put it on the fire and wiped it, and put the paper in the fire; I said the ladle was nasty and smelt very strong; he said never mind it: on Monday morning when the horse was dead, he came into the shop where I was at work, and put his hands together and said, I would not have it known I gave the horse any thing for that full of gold; and held his two hands together in this manner (describing it): I never saw him give this horse any medicines in my life before.

JOHN BUCKLE
sworn.

I had a horse of Mr. Whitbread's under my care with a fore leg: Mr. Edwards had him in hand, but could not cure him; he gave him up; I took him in hand and got him so well, that he could walk about; Edwards begged to have him again; he had him about a month; in which time he grew so bad that he flung him up again, and in nine days time I got him so well as to be able to go to grass; I was ordered to take some grass at Islington, and he was to come on Monday: upon Saturday morning I dressed the horse, and he was in full health; on Monday morning between four and five o'clock the horse-keeper called me up and told me the horse was dead; I went to the stable and found the horse dead; I clapped my hands on the flanks of the horse and said he was poisoned; then I looked behind at his burden, and he began to purge, and a great deal of stuff came from him: I would not go away till I saw the horse opened; they cut a gut and the stuff ran out; I desired to have the paunch out whole; I took the paunch out whole and opened it with my knife, and upon the point of my knife I saw this yellow arsenic, and the paper; it had been done up in the ball with the paper; it was digested, and there was the paper.

Do you undertake to say the horse died of that and nothing else? - Nothing else at all; I think the man that bought it and pounded it for him was as deep in the mud as he was in the mire; they gave the horse two ounces, an ounce would have done.

Was the horse taking any balls at this time? - None at all; the horse was in good health; this is the stuff (producing it) that I took from the horse; there is yellow arsenic among it: there was a dispute between Edwards and me about the horse; I do not believe the prisoner would have done it if he had not been bid.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

All I have to say is, it was by my master's orders that I gave the horse this; I asked Scott what the stuff was; I did not know; he said he did and would fetch it for me; it was brought to me made up in a ball; Blanden was not tall enough to give it the horse, and so I gave it him.
FOR THE PRISONER.

JOHN STEVENS
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. Whitbread: I saw Edwards give a ball to Blanden on the Sunday morning before the horse died; I did not see it given him.
BLANDEN. There was another horse in the stable that was ill: Edwards gave the prisoner two balls, and bid him give that horse one in the morning and the other in the afternoon.

JOHN LIGHTFOOT
sworn.
I heard some words between Edwards and his men in the stable; he said he would not be run down by the old man that had the horse in hand, and called him an old rogue; I did not see any balls given.

CATHERINE NORTON
sworn.

Upon the 2d of May Storer's wife came to me and desired me to go with her to receive what trifle of money was due to him; we went to his master, and she asked for the money; he gave her two half crowns which were due to him; I said to him, it was a sad thing this boy was suffering by his order; he made answer, My dear woman, and shook very much, I know nothing of the matter, I knew nothing of its being transacted; he knew it was to be done, but not the time it was to be transacted; had he known it, he would have prevented so many being by when it was done: when he spoke these words, his wife called him back and said, Mr. Edwards, come back, these women are come to take hold of your words: I said, Ma'am, we are not come here to take hold of any body's words; but you have put them in our mouths: then I said to Mrs. Edwards, is not this woman's husband as dear to her as yours is to you? Mr. Edwards said, yes, my dear, he is; he trembled very much and clapped the door against me.
The prisoner called four witnesses, who gave him a good character.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the Second Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

475.
JOHN TUNSTED
was indicted for the
wilfull murder of
Grace Clark
, widow, by striking and beating her with a stick on the top of the head, and thereby giving her a mortal wound of the length of two inches and of the depth of one inch, of which she languished from the 27th of February unto the 1st of May, and then died .

He was charged on the Coroner's Inquisition with killing and slaying the said
Grace Clark
.

THOMAS LOVEGRAVE
sworn.
I am beadle of St. Andrew's of the liberty of Saffron-hill: I know nothing of the fact; I am bound over to prosecute.

ELIZABETH WEST
sworn.

I live at Saffron-hill work-house
: the prisoner lives at the same place; he used to cut bread and draw beer; I am one of the nurses in the nursery; I knew the deceased, she was likewise in the work-house: at the latter end of last February
Grace Clark
came into the nursery to light her pipe between twelve and one o'clock, as near as I can guess; the prisoner's wife, who is the other nurse, and some boys, who were at dinner, and I were in the nursery; just as she had lighted her pipe and was going into her own apartment, the prisoner came and asked her what business she had there? and hit her with a stick twice on the top part of her head; she had not said any thing to him; the blood ran from her head upon her shoulder; I took hold of her by her shoulder and put her into her own ward; she staid a few minutes and came out of the ward again; then he slapp'd her on the face, and she made a curtsey to him and thanked him; we bid her go out into her own ward again; there was no provocation given him at that time; she made him a curtsey and went into her own ward; she died the last day of April: I never heard her complain of these blows afterwards, she seemed to be stupid.
More so than she used to be? - Yes.
Was any thing done to her head? - I don't know that, I cannot say.

THOMAS PROBERT
sworn.
How old are you? - Thirteen years.
Do you know the nature of an oath? do you know what would become of you if you was to swear false? - I should be in danger of hell.

Do you remember
Grace Clark
coming in while you was at dinner to light her pipe? - Yes; Mr. Tunsted hit her twice over the head with this stick; by striking her over the head, the blood ran down her shoulders.
LOVEGRAVE. This stick has been kept ever since at the work-house.
Had the old woman said any thing to Tunsted before he gave her these two blows? PROBERT. Not a word.
Do you remember her coming into the nursery the second time? - Yes, and he followed her again; he hit her once or twice in the landing place as she was going down.
Whereabouts did he hit her? - I did not see.

ANN DUROSE
sworn.
The woman died upon the 1st of May.

Do you know whether there was any quarrel between Tunsted and her? - No, she told me before she died, and two or three people in the same ward, that she fell down and hit her head against the bed screw; she said that about a week before she died.
Can you tell what part of her head she hit? - The top of her head; I put a plaister to it: it was about a week before she died that I perceived her head was bloody.
How came she to hit it against the bed-screw? - Her head swam.
Do you know what state of health she was in before that? - No.
Did you perceive any other wound at the time you put the plaister upon her head? - No, I did not.
Was there any bruise where you put the plaister? - I only saw a little hole at the top of her head, and I put a plaister to it; that was all I saw.
Did any apothecary or surgeon take care of her? - No, we did not apprehend that there was any danger at all in it.

CATHERINE HINCKSMAN
sworn.

The deceased was brought up to me as nurse in the ward; I was going to put her into bed; I pulled her cap off and I perceived a hole in the top of her head; that was about a week or ten days before she died; the hole at the top of her head was like an issue hole; I said, Grace, you have got a hole in your head, how came you by it? said she, My dear soul, I fell down and hit it against the screw of the bedstead: I got some lint and made a poultice, and put it into the hole of her head, and put a plaister on it.
How long did she live after that? - I believe eight or nine days, and then she died.

Do you know any thing of the condition of her health before that? - She was pretty hearty, but she went out of the house and came in again; she was about seventy years of age: I heard her make no complaint, but she seemed stupid and would ramble; we used to think she made herself wicked; that was about a month or six weeks before she died; she seemed like superannuated, and was very silly about the house.
No surgeon looked at it? - We never heard a word of it she was so stupefied, and so intolerably wicked she would go into any body's place and rob them.

JOHN METCALF
sworn.

I am in the work-house: I heard that the prisoner and the deceased had broke one another's pipes; they were both smoakers; I heard a noise; I saw him strike her with a stick four times about the head; this was about a month after the affair in the nursery; she was quite stupefied for a long time afterwards; she lived about three weeks after she received these blows; she struck him three blows.
Who struck first? - He.
What was the occasion of this? - About breaking the pipes; they were both smoaking; they stood close by the fire place.
Whereabouts upon the head did he hit her? - It came down by the side of her shoulders; he hit her upon the head.
Did you see them break the pipes? - No; I was ten yards off.
What did she hit him with? - A broomstick; he hit her with an oak stick that he used to walk with.
Were they violent blows? - They came pretty sharp.
Did it break her head? - I saw no blood; I was not near her.
BIDDY LYON sworn.

The last quarrel the prisoner had, was in regard to breaking her pipe; it commenced upon her stealing a piece of cloth out of his box, and a linen apron of a woman's; she hid it for the space of five or six days; a good woman there found them concealed under the head of her bed; words arose upon that; he gave her a blow upon the shoulder, she up with a broomstick that she had, to strike him again.
Was Metcalf by? - Yes.

How many times did he strike her? - I believe twice upon the shoulder; in four or five days afterwards there was a report about the house that Tunsted cut
Grace Clark
's head; he came down and said to her, is not this a fine report that I cut your head? she replied, My dear man, you never hurt me; I was taken with a swimming in my head, and fell down against the bedstead, and cut it with the screw: there were several in the shop heard these words besides me.
You do not know how she came to have a swimming in her head? - No.

LEONARD SMITH
sworn.
I am master of the work-house.

You knew this
Grace Clark
? - Very well.

Do you know any thing of any blows that were given her by Tunsted? - Upon the 19th of April she came out of the fore yard, and sat in the upper yard; our window looks directly where she sat; I saw her cap bloody; I sent one of the women, and went myself; I asked her how she came by that, she said her head swam, and she fell against the bed-screw, and that made her head bloody; the women took her in doors, and dressed her head: she was taken ill on the 25th, and continued so till the 1st of May, when she died.

JOHN DALE
sworn.
I did not see this old woman till she was dead.

Do you attend the work-house as surgeon? - No; there is an apothecary attends it; when there are any chirurgical cases that require assistance, they are sent to the hospital; I was called a day or two after the death by desire of the apothecary to inspect her head, as they did imagine it had been the cause of her death; on taking off the cap I saw a small bruise, about the size of a silver groat, exactly upon the top of her head; I took my probe, passed it into the wound, and was very much astonished to find that it went in four inches between the two hemispheres of the brain; I then, in the presence of the apothecary, and some other gentlemen, denuded the skull, by taking off a piece of the scalp; I could not discover any trace of a fracture; the bone was very offensive and very carious about the size of a shilling; I then took out a piece of the bone; I trepanned her; I found the two coverings of the brain were gangreened, and eat quite through; and I undertake to pronounce that that wound, however it happened, was the cause of her death.
By what sort of instrument did that wound seem to be given? - It might be altered in its appearance by being neglected, that it is hard to say; it must have been by a considerable bruise.

You have heard that she fell against a screw of the bed, and that she had two violent blows with that stick that broke her head; did it appear to you that her falling against a screw might occasion this? - It might; it must be some hard body that had done it, whether it was a bed-screw or a stick, or what other body, it is impossible to say; it had been of some standing, the bone could not have been so carious, as it was, soon.

How long would it take to occasion that; might it in three weeks? - Yes, it might; it depends a great deal upon the habit of the body; she was 75 years of age, and wrong applications might encrease it.
Did you see what had been applied to it? - They told me some yellow basilicon.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I never struck her at all; that very juncture of time there was another squabble in another ward; she was knocked down, and hit her head against the bedstead, Mrs. Durose knows that.
Mrs. DUROSE. I gave her a small push, and she fell down against the bedstead and scratched the bottom of her head near her neck, we got a bit of loaf-sugar and put to it.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. Justice ASTON.

476.
JOHN MORGAN
was indicted for
stealing a piece of moreen, containing twenty-four yards, value forty shillings, and 144 yards of silk and worsted bed-lace, value eighteen shillings , the property of
William Sampson
and
Richard Sampson
, May 4th .
MAJOR HAXBY sworn.

William and
Richard Sampson
are wholesale upholsterers
; I am a manager for them; on the 4th of April I packed up a parcel of moreen, and a gross of bed-lace, and directed it to
Edward Goodyer
, at Dover; it was delivered by our porter to the wharfiners at the keys, and the wharfage paid; about an hour after, the prisoner was detected with it.

ROBERT SHIRLEY
sworn.

I was standing at Bear-key
about five o'clock in the evening; I saw the prisoner take the parcel and put it in his apron, and go up the gate-way, I followed him; there was a cart stood in the gate-way that he could not get by; he dropped the parcel; Mansfield, who was with me, took it up, and we secured him.

John Mansfield
, a merchant's watchman, confirmed the evidence of
Robert Shirley
.
- Ward, the constable to whom the parcel was delivered by Mansfield, produced it in court, and it was deposed to by Haxby.
The prisoner in his defence, said he was not guilty, and called one witness, who gave him a good character.
GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

477.
WILLIAM KITCHINMAN
was indicted for
stealing a pewter quart pot, value two shillings , the property of
Joseph Stevens
, May 20th .
- FOWLER sworn.
I stopt the prisoner with a pint pot in his coat pocket, and a quart pot in his breeches; I took him to the sign of the Rainbow, where the pots were taken from him.

THOMAS STEVENS
sworn.

I keep the Rainbow; a pint pot of mine was found in the prisoner's pocket; he had a quart pot in his breeches; I saw it taken out; it belonged to
Joseph Stevens
; he was sent for.

JOSEPH STEVENS
sworn.

I keep the Five Bells, a public-house in New-bridge-street, Black-friars; the prisoner came into my house last Monday; he had a pint of beer, which he paid for, and went away; in about an hour after I was sent for to the Rainbow, and was informed my pot was found upon him.

[The pot was produced in court by
Samuel Lee
, and was deposed to by the prosecutor.]
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I picked the pot up in the street; I was much intoxicated with liquor, I did not know what I did.
The prisoner called two witnesses, who gave him a good character.

GUILTY .
B .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

478.
JAMES BLACKETT
was indicted for
stealing a wooden band-box covered with paper, value three shillings, a silk gown, value five pounds, a worked muslin apron, value fifteen shillings, a pair of worked muslin ruffles, value fifteen shillings, seven yards of black silk lace, value fifteen shillings, a gold enamelled mourning ring, value fifteen shillings, a pair of womens' silk gloves, value four shillings, four yards of white thread lace, value ten shillings, a gauze laced cap, value seven shillings, five guineas, and a half guinea, the property of
Sarah Robinson
, spinster , in the dwelling-house of a certain person unknown , Jan. 8th .

SARAH ROBINSON
sworn.

I live in Newmarket-street, May-fair, upon what I have: on the 8th of January I was robbed of a band-box, containing the several things mentioned in the indictment (repeating them) the box had a lock and key upon it; it was in a public house, the prisoner and another man took it from me between three and four in the afternoon; I was going to a place, in Covent-garden, I don't know what street; we were in the parlour backwards.

Was you acquainted with the prisoner? - No; I never saw him but once before, he came to my apartments and said he was sent by the other man; the other man and I went into the parlour together; he told me his name was Fletcher, but the prisoner told me his name was Davis.

Was Fletcher your acquaintance? - No; some time before I met him in the street, he called me by my name, and asked me where I was going, and if I did not know him in the country? I said I knew nothing of him; he said he would go home with me, and said he was a linen-draper in York-street, Covent-garden; he came to me afterwards to my place, and asked me if I had received any linen; he said he had sent me a great quantity by a porter, and as I had not received the linen, he must take up the porter, but he could not do it without I paid him some money first; and upon that I gave him five guineas; he came to me afterwards, and asked me to go and live servant with his sister-in-law; I agreed to go, and took my band-box and things with me, and went with him; I thought to go to the place, and he took me into a public house, and called for six-penny worth of brandy and water, and the prisoner came in; I put the band-box on a table in the parlour of the public house; they called each other out, and spoke to one another at the door; I said I did not chuse to be so late at my place, and told the other man I would not stop; that was between three and four in the afternoon; I sat about a quarter of an hour, then I looked behind me on the table, and my box was gone.
Were they both in the room? - Yes, they were both together.
Did you see your band-box in the room after they went out and talked together? - No, I did not look.

How long did they stay out talking? - I saw no more of them; I don't know when the box was taken away, nor by which of them; I called the maid, and asked her if they were gone; she said she did not know; I asked the master, and he said they paid for the six-penny worth of brandy and water, and ran fast down the yard.

You never saw the prisoner before; are you sure he is the man? - Yes; two or three days before he was taken, he came into the house where I was to take possession of some goods; I said I thought I knew him, and asked him if his name was not Blackett? he said it was; I had heard his name mentioned when they were together; the other man called him Blackett; and then I asked him where the other was? he said if I would give him a bottle of wine, or some money, he would tell me.
Cross Examination.
What are you? - I live upon what I have, I had 3000 l. left me.
Did you say any thing to any body about this trial yesterday? - Not that I know.

Did you say if this man would give you five guineas you would not appear against him? - I said no such thing; I said if the person would come and pay me half my money and half my expences, the bill might be thrown out; and he said he would put me in a way of doing it.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I was put in possession of the house where this lady was a lodger, I was there four days and nights, and we breakfasted, dined, and supped together, and nothing was said about it.
He called four witnesses, who gave him a good character.

GUILTY .
Death .

Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

479.
THOMAS ASKEW
,
JOSEPH BISSELL
, and
ANN HORNER
, were indicted for
feloniously and traiterously forging, counterfeiting, and coining a piece of false, feigned, and counterfeit money and coin to the likeness and similitude of the silver coin of this realm, called a shilling, against the statute .

2d Count. For feloniously and traiterously forging, counterfeiting, and coining one piece of false, feigned, and counterfeit money and coin to the likeness of the silver coin of this realm, called a six-pence, against the statute, April 17 .

RICHARD BRYANT
sworn.

I am an officer at Sir
John Fielding
's: I went with Mr. Clark, the first day of last sessions, to a house by Battle-bridge-wells, in Britania-street, I believe it is; Mr. Clark first sent a gentleman's servant with a letter in his hand for Mr Askew, to get the easier admittance into the house; the door was opened by Mrs. Horner, myself and Mr. Evans rushed into the house; we immediately ran up stairs, and upon the garret stairs, within three or four steps of the top, I met Askew; he had got on a cheque shirt, the sleeves of which were tucked up, and the collar was unbuttoned; he pressed very much to come down stairs; we had a little struggle with him; I insisted upon his going up stairs, and we forced him up: when we met him on the stairs, Bissell ran out of a garret that is on the left hand into a garret that fronts the stairs; we took Askew into the front garret, and kept him there till Mr. Clark came.

How was Bissell dressed? - He had his coat off, a silk handkerchief tied round his head, his breeches knees were unbuttoned, he had no garters on, and was in a sweat; they both seemed to be in a working condition; their hands were all over mould and sand; they both wanted much to wash their hands, but I would not let them till Mr. Clark came up: in the front garret there was a forge fixed, a crucible upon the fire, with some metal in it, and a large quantity of charcoal lying by; there were the flasks; there was some sand, which was hot, that must have been just made use of; there was scouring-paper, and a bottle of aqua-fortis; these were all in the front garret, into which Bissell ran; there was a small earthen tea-cup, with some pickle in it, which is used in that business, and some water in a quart stone pan, of a greenish colour; there was, in a larger pan, some very dirty water, and by that was a scrubbing-brush, and a little earthen platter, with some common scouring sand, and the floor was wet where they had been scouring something, I suppose the counterfeit silver.
Who were in company? - Clark, Evans, Heley, myself, and a gentleman's servant. I went some few days afterwards with Mrs. Horner, and found some scouring-paper, and some few other things.

JOHN EVANS
sworn.

I was at the Old Bailey last Sessions; Mr. Clark came up to me, and said there were some coiners in my parish, and asked me, as being constable of the parish, to go with him; I went with him to this street, I think it is called Britannia-street; it is near Bagnigge-wells; Mr. Clark, Mr. Bryant, Mr. Heley, and I, went together, a gentleman's servant went with us, with a great coat, whip, and pair of boots; Mr. Clark gave him a letter, and bid him knock at the door, under pretence of asking for a person; the door was opened by Mrs. Horner; while he was speaking to Mrs. Horner, Mr. Bryant and I rushed by him; Mrs. Horner cried out, Master, four distinct times; we immediately rushed up to the garret; when we came almost to the landing-place of the garret, Askew was down one step or two; he had a cheque shirt on, his sleeves were tucked up, his collar was unbuttoned, he had no garters, his breeches knees were loose, and, if I remember right, the flap of his shirt was out before, and his hands excessive dirty, as if he had been working in some sand, or something of that kind: Bryant laid hold of him; I ran into the room to the other people, and we tied their hands; they wanted to wash their hands, we would not let them; the other prisoner ran out of the back into the fore room; we tied both of their hands there; Bissell's hands were very dirty and whitish. When I told Askew that Mr. Clark was there, he said, I would not have minded if all the men in England had taken me, if it had not been Mr. Clark; Clark blamed him, and asked him how he could do so; he said, He could not help it, it was now too late to talk about it; Mr. Clark shook his head, and said, O Tom, Tom, how could you do so! Mr. Clark, said he, it is over, and I cannot help it; Mr. Clark said, now, Tom, be candid, do show us where the things are; we searched the fore room, we found every implement that was there as was described by the other witness; then said Askew, If you will come along with me I will shew you where they all are; we went into a back room; there was a wide large chest, upon which were files, scouring-paper, and some shillings and six-pences, and upon the floor on the right hand side going in, there was, I believe, a hundred shillings, six-pences, and half-crowns; I saw likewise the aqua fortis: there was a crucible on the fire red hot, whether there was metal in it or no I could not be certain, as it was thrown on one side; I found some sand, which was broke up, that was hot; there were some moulds that the flasks had been fixed in; there were some files, scouring-paper, and a little pipkin with some wet stuff prepared, and there was another bason of water in the room of a green colour; Mr. Clark put his hand into that, and took out some shillings and six-pences: there was a scrubbing-brush lay down by the side of it.
Did you see any forge? - That was in the fore room; it is not properly a forge, it is the same the refiners use on purpose to melt in.

What quantity of counterfeit money did you see in both rooms? - I believe twelve half-crowns, and half a hat full of shillings; I found three shillings on Mrs. Horner, which were good; I asked her why she gave a report to Mr. Askew that we were coming? she said she thought she had a just right so to do.

JOHN CLARK
sworn.

The first that I saw in the house that I knew was
Ann Horner
; Bryant and Evans were at that time up stairs in the garret; they called me up; when I came up I saw the two men prisoners: Mr. Askew was in a cheque shirt, and an old pair of breeches, his stockings were about his heels, and he had on a pair of slippers; he was rather in a sweat; his hands were daubed all over with a sort of mould that was found in the room; the other man had a handkerchief tied round his head, his stockings were down: he was taken down into the one pair of stairs to tie up his stockings, and he begged to be washed, which was refused him; at that time his hands were the same as the other: Bissell's hands were green.

How came they so? - I fancy by handling metal, or something of that sort: we went into the front garret first, there I found a furnace, some call it a forge; it is an air furnace which they melt metal in; a crucible on the fire, with some metal in it, two pair of flasks, some sand in a box which is here, warm; there was a quart pan with some water, and by the side of that was a tea-cup with something green in it; it appeared to be aqua-fortis and water.

You call that pickle, don't you? - We do; there was a bottle with aqua-fortis; in the quart pan I found these three counterfeit shillings (producing them): I begged Askew would not give me any trouble, but shew me where all the things were; then he took me into the back garret adjoining to the other; the first things I saw in the back garret were three files, and other things (producing them) a bottle of aqua-fortis: these flasks are made use of in casting; whatever is cast, in making the first part of the mould sand is laid, the sand itself is of a porous nature, and would leave it spongy if cast in sand alone, but here is some facing, which, when put upon it, fills up the pores of the sand, and strengthens it, and it is cast much smoother.
Court. Can these flasks be applied to any other purpose than that of coining money? - Yes; they can be used in the silversmiths business.

Court. Then all we understand from it is, that these flasks are used for coining silver, but may be applied to other purposes? - Yes; searching Bissell's person I found these two shillings (producing them) and here are two six-pences.

Are these bad shillings? - They are, and the six pences are bad; he had these in his pocket: in the back garret where all these things were, I found these finished shillings; and here is the metal that was in the paper; here are the files, they have something white in the teeth, but that may be done with something else; all the words that passed that I heard was, Askew said he wished we had not come so soon, if we had been half an hour later, it would all have been over; that he did not intend to coin any more, for he had took a house in Smithfield, and paid ten guineas earnest; Bissell said he came to help him move his goods: there were no goods there to carry away; there was only a great trunk or box which they worked upon by way of a work bench.
Had you any conversation with Mrs. Horner? - Not any thing particular; her hands were examined, they were green, the same as Bissell's were.
Cross Examination.
I believe you are a silversmith? - I am more in the cane head way; I have worked in both.
Are you skilled in the casting of silver and other metals? - I am.

You have given an account that these flasks may be used in casting other metals besides coining; I suppose your knowledge goes so far as to know that every tool produced here may be used for many other purposes besides coining? - Every thing besides the money.

WILLIAM MACKENZIE
sworn.
Do you know either of the prisoners? - Yes, I know them all.
Have you ever had occasion to be at their house at Battle-bridge? - Yes.

What have you seen there? - I have seen Askew, Horner, and Bissell in a room together; there were a quantity of half crowns upon a chest; I have seen them twice; Askew sat upon a chair,
Ann Horner
upon another chair, Bissell upon the end of the chest,
Thomas Askew
had a six-pence between his fingers; it appeared to me to be counterfeit money that he had before him; he was filing it round;
Ann Horner
had a pair of pincers in her left hand, and a shilling in the pincers, a cork and a piece of scouring paper round it in her right hand, a scouring of it from side to side; Bissell had a pair of pincers before him; that is all I saw at that time; that was the 21st of March.
Did you see any thing between the 8th of March and the 21st, besides what you have spoke of? - No.
How long was you with them? - I staid six or seven minutes; I took up one of the half crowns and examined it, and said it was very well executed.

Court. Gentlemen of the Jury, you observe this witness speaks to a fact the other witnesses have not spoke of, and as to this particular fact he is confirmed by no one, therefore we will not take his evidence as any thing.

WILLIAM TONGUE
sworn.

I am the landlord of the house at Battle-bridge: I let the house to the prisoner
William Askew
, a little better than half a year ago.
Court to EVANS. Was there any bed in any of the garrets? - No, nor any kind of furniture as I saw; I believe I was in every room of the house.

JOSEPH SAY
sworn.

I am a monier belonging to the mint: this money is very bad, there can be no doubt; if you rub them on a bit of sand you see they are copper immediately; they are all of them very bad; the best not worth above two-pence or a penny a piece (one shewn him); I have seen several; this is as good as any of them, and it is as bad as bad can be.
Cross Examination.
Whether that very bad shilling, which is as bad as bad can be, strongly resembles the current coin of this kingdom? - They are so covered, I frequently take them myself by candlelight.
To CLARK. Whether they were not duller than they are now when you found them, and not so much like the current coin? - They were more like the current coin.
ASKEW's DEFENCE.
To the best of my knowledge there was no such thing as a had shilling in the house.
BISSELL's DEFENCE.
The reason of my being at Askew's house was, he asked me to help him remove his goods.

ANN HORNER
's DEFENCE.
I kept Mr. Askew's house; if he did any thing amiss it was unknown to me.
Askew called five witnesses, two of whom said he dealt in steel chains, and all of them gave him a good character.
Bissell called eight witnesses, who gave him a good character.

ANN HORNER
. I thought they were bailiffs when they came to the house.

ASKEW
GUILTY .
Death .

BISSELL
GUILTY .
Death .

HORNER
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

480, 481.
WILLIAM FLOOD
and
WILLIAM DAVIS
were indicted for
that they in the King's highway, in and upon
Francis Coquiltart
did make an assault, putting him in corporal fear and danger of his life, and stealing a watch in a gold case, value 4 l. a steel watch chain, value one shilling, three metal watch keys, value one shilling, a guinea, and three half crowns, the property of the said Francis from his person , April the 27th .
There was no other witness but the prosecutor, who could not swear to the persons of either of the prisoners.
The watch was not produced, nor were there any other circumstance to prove the charge upon the prisoners.

BOTH
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

482.
WILLIAM THOMAS
was indicted for
that he in the King's highway, in and upon
William Holmes
did make an assault, putting him in corporal fear and danger of his life, and stealing from his person a silver watch, value forty shillings, the property of the said William , May the 5th .
The prosecutor and prisoner quarrelled in the street; but there was no evidence of any intent to commit a robbery.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

483.
JOHN REYNOLDS
was indicted for
stealing ten stones called Yorkshire paving stones, value twelve shillings , the property of
William Staines
, March the 16th .
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

484, 485.
JAMES LECORES
and
WILLIAM GODFREY
were indicted for
stealing twenty-nine guineas, a half guinea, and eight shillings and six-pence in money numbered, the property of
Daniel Dance
, and a bank note for 20 l. the property of the said Daniel in the dwelling house of
Mary Troutbeck
, widow , May the 6th .

DANIEL DANCE
sworn.

I live at Camberwell: I lost a 20 l. bank note, twenty-nine guineas, a half guinea, and eight shillings and six-pence at Mrs. Troutbeck's, the Queen's Head Inn, Gray's-inn-lane
; I took the money to Mr. Child's at Temple-bar; the office was shut up; I came away, and while I was looking up at a house near Temple-bar, Godfrey came up and said, Farmer, what are you looking at? I told him I came to pay my rent to my landlord, and the office was shut up; he said he came out of Kent to a lawyer, and he supposed he was too late to meet with him; we walked together and he talked of some people in Kent; he mentioned the names of several I was well acquainted with; I said I would carry the money to Mr. Silway's chambers, for I would not carry it back again; he said he would go with me and shew me his chambers; we went up Chancery-lane and crossed Holborn into Gray's-inn-lane; we went about two hundred yards up and down, and then he said, if I would go into a public house we might have intelligence; we went into a public house, and he called for six-penny worth of Crank, and he asked me if I would sit down; I sat down, and in came the other prisoner and pulled out a purse of money, and said he had drank fourteen glasses of brandy that morning standing; he said he was a captain just come home: we went out from there, and he said he would shew me the way to Mr. Silway's chambers; then we went into Mrs. Troutbeck's and called for a bottle of wine; they hit my knuckles with a half-penny, and then asked me to put the half-penny under a bottle; while I was doing it they took the money out of my pocket; I saw the money in their hand, but they ran away so fast I could not speak; they broke a glass in their hurry in running out; the money was in a bag in my coat pocket.
When they run out you felt in your pocket? - Yes, it was gone; I saw the bag in their hands, and the note was in the bag.
Cross Examination.
Whose hands did you see the money in? - Godfrey's.

Did you ever see these people before? - Never before; he appeared like a country farmer; I know them as well as any man in the parish I live in; I know Godfrey by his backside; I took him by the tail; I have been always positive to him; he was taken the Tuesday after the Duchess of Kingston's trial.
Was that a week or a fortnight after you was plundered? - I believe it was about a fortnight.
You knew the man immediately? - Yes; I pursued him every day; he owned he had the money; his friends offered me thirty pounds.

WILLIAM SWAN
sworn.

I live with Mrs. Troutbeck: the prosecutor and three more came into our house on Easter Monday, and asked for a pot of beer; I told them we did not sell beer; then they called for a bottle of wine; I stood in the passage to watch them, lest they should go away and not pay the reckoning; three of them came out very sharp, and put two shillings in my hand; I asked my mistress how much it was, she said two shillings; I went in to see if there were any glasses broke, and met the old farmer coming out; a glass was broke; I asked him if he was to pay for the glass, he said he had lost enough: I know the prisoners are two of the men; they owned before the justice they had the money, but said they got it by gambling.
LECORES' DEFENCE.
A parcel of people about me desired me to say so, and they would clear me; I was in liquor and did not know what I did.
GODFREY's DEFENCE.
I leave it to my counsel.
Godfrey called four witnesses, who gave him a good character.
From the Jury to DANCE. Whether they used any other means besides that of the bottle to divert you? - Nothing in the world; there was no gaming.
How long might it be from the time you went in to the time they ran away? - Not above ten minutes.

BOTH
GUILTY .
Death .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

486, 487.
WILLIAM HURST
and
JOHN MAYO
