were indicted for
assaulting
Joseph Collins
with certain offensive weapons called knives, with a felonious intent to steal the monies of the said Joseph from his person, against the statute , May the 24th .
"It appeared upon the evidence that the
"prisoners are coachmen; they had a dispute
"about a watch which was in the possession
"of the prosecutor; the prisoners stopped him,
"and Hurst insisted upon having the watch
"he had given the other to pawn; but
"there did not appear to be any felonious
"intention."

BOTH
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the First Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

488, 489, 490.
RICHARD REES
,
ROBERT ROBERTS
, and
WILLIAM FLOOD
were indicted for
that they in a certain field and open place near the King's highway, in and upon
James Trimbey
did make an assault, putting him in corporal fear and danger of his life, and stealing from his person a guinea and one shilling in money numbered, the property of the said James , April the 26th .
The prosecutor was called, and not appearing his recognizance was ordered to be estreated.

ALL THREE
NOT GUILTY .

491, 492.
GEORGE ROWNEY , otherwise ROWLEY
, and
THOMAS ROWNEY , otherwise ROWLEY
, were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Mattison
on the 20th of May about the hour of two in the night, and stealing a French bill of exchange for 101 l. 10 s. ninety-eight yards of black sattin, eight guineas, and a crown piece, the property of the said Thomas in his dwelling-house .
2d Count. For stealing the bill and goods in the dwelling-house, omitting the charge of burglary.
The witnesses were examined apart at the request of the prisoners.

THOMAS MATTISON
sworn.

I keep a haberdasher's shop in King-street, Cheapside
; my house was broke open last Monday night; I went to bed about one o'clock; my servant fastened the house.

JOSEPH PARKER
sworn.

I am servant to Mr. Mattison: I fastened every part of my master's house on Monday night last; when I got up in the morning I found the chain down and the door on the single lock; I went into the compting-house and found the compting-house window shoved down; it opens from the top; there was a half shutter, which was no t taken down; there is a pane of glass broke in the window; I found the window broke and my master's desk open; I went and informed my master of it directly.
Did you double lock the door and put the chain up over night? - Yes, my master saw me do it.
Is it a spring lock that will shut with pulling to? - Yes.
What o'clock did you find it broke open? - Between seven and eight; I was the first person up.

Mr. MATTISON. My servant called me on the Tuesday morning, and told me the house was broke open; I went down and found the compting-house window broke; it was cut at the bottom; my desk, which had been wrenched open, was in great confusion, all the papers were moved; I looked into the drawer I keep my bills in, and every bill was gone, eight guineas, and several silver pocket pieces were likewise taken away; I referred to the bill book immediately that I might stop payment of the bills; I found many leaves had been torn out; this is the book (producing it) all the leaves were torn out that contained the bills that I had received last year.
Here is a French bill of exchange, you speak particularly to that bill? - Yes.
Do you know the date of it? - No, it is here.
From the JURY. Did you see your servant fasten up the doors that night? - I did.
Were all the bills safe that night when you went to bed? - I went out at four o'clock.
Was the bill book safe that night? - I believe so, I did not look at it; I cannot say that I had seen it that day.

[The note produced by
John Wightwick
.]
Was that one of your bills? - Yes, it has my own hand writing on it, marking the day it would become due.

Did you suspect any one being concerned in this? - I imagined it must be somebody that had lived in the house, and knew I entered the bills in that book; one of the prisoners (the boy) had lived with me; he left me in November: there was some blood on the glass that was broke, as if somebody had cut their finger.

Did you ever find any of your bills again besides this? - Yes, all of them: I lost some black silk and black sattin (the silks and sattins produced): I have looked at them all and sealed them up; I am sure they are my own property; they have my own private mark upon them.
What is the value of them? - I cannot say; I believe about eighteen or nineteen pounds; they were in a press by the desk; they are all stained with blood; I saw them not many days before.

MOSES MORANT
sworn.

Last Tuesday morning Mr. Mattison came to Sir
John Fielding
's, and laid an information; I went with him to find the prisoners lodging, at Mr. Wheeler's, No. 20, Great Wild-street; I asked for the prisoners; they were not at home; we could not get into the room; we staid till past four o'clock: I went up expecting to find him there; the door was fast; I asked for him; I was told he was in the house; I went up stairs and looked in his room; the door was fast as when I saw it in the morning; I went down and met a woman; I asked her if she had seen him; she said she had, and believed he was in the yard, or with the landlady; this woman came down stairs with me, and went into Mrs. Wheeler's room; she told Mr. Rowney there was one wanted him; he came out and asked me what I wanted with him; I told him he must go with me; he begged to go back to lock up his room, and to let the landlady know, for he had a child to come home in the evening; he then went into Mrs. Wheeler's room, and as he was going in he pulled out of his pocket this gold watch, which he offered to the landlady; I told him he should not leave it there, for I would take it from him, if he did not put it in his pocket again; he put it in his pocket again, and desired me not to make any disturbance or noise; he told me tea was made for him, and he wished to drink a dish of tea before he went; he drank two dishes; he then asked to go into the yard to make water; I told him he might do so; as he was going out of the door one step, he
drew
the watch out of his pocket again; I was afraid he would fling it away, or do something with it; I struggled with him for it; he then desired I would not make any disturbance; he put it into his pocket again: I took him away directly to the office in Bow-street; there I searched him; out of his pocket I took that watch, fourteen guineas, a new knife, four pawnbrokers duplicates, and his needles, I think: then I told Mr. Bond that there was nobody on the spot, and I was apprehensive the son would come home, and I wanted to go back again; I left the father in safe custody, and went back to the place, and staid there till between seven and eight o'clock.
Did the landlady know what you took him away for? - No; I did not tell any body in the house, for fear they should tell the son.

Did she know you was an officer? - She understood that I had got him upon an arrest; she said, I hope the debt is not much? I made answer, it is not five pounds; I went back and staid till between seven and eight o'clock; then the son came home; he went a few steps up stairs, and seeing me coming after him, he turned back again; I turned him about, and shoved him up stairs before me; when I came to the door. he pulled the key out of his pocket himself; but, in his fright, and being rather in liquor, he did not open the door: at this time
Charles Jealous
came to assist me, and Halliburton soon after; then I took the key out of his hand, and opened the door myself; we shoved him into the room: Jealous searched one side of him, and I the other; out of his right hand breeches pocket I took two ten pounds Bank post bills; then out of his waistcoat pocket I took eighteen guineas; Jealous took the money out of his other pocket, and the watch; then we searched the room; upon the table between the two windows I found some papers, and four bills of exchange, and in the window there lay some leaves of Mr. Mattison's bill book.
Mr. MATTISON. These leaves were torn out of my bill book; the entries are my own hand-writing.

MORANT. We found five pieces of sattin in the drawer, and two at the bed's head under the bolster; then we tied up all the things that we could find, that we thought belonged to Mr. Mattison, and brought the young man away: I forgot to tell you that I took the key of the street door where the lodging was out of the father's pocket.
Did you observe either of their hands cut? - No.

CHARLES JEALOUS
sworn.

I was at the lodgings at the time young Rowney came in; I found upon him this gold watch (producing it) I found 14 guineas and a half in gold, and in his pocket I found a watch-maker's bill, and a note for seventeen pounds; in a little box in the same room I found this remarkable piece (producing it).
Mr. MATTISON. It is mine; it is a medal of king Charles on horseback.
JEALOUS. I found seven pieces of silk and sattin; two of them were under the bed.
Prisoner. I had eighteen guineas in my pocket when they took me.

WILLIAM HALLIBURTON
sworn.
I was at the searching of the room; I found these tapes, these memorandum-books, &c.
Mr. MATTISON. I believe these are my property; they have taken off the marks, so I cannot be positive to them.

JOHN WIGHTWICK
sworn.
I am a watch-maker in Ludgate-street.

Do you remember selling any watches to the prisoners? - Yes;
Thomas Rowney
, the young man, had a repeating watch, the name Hughes, the other a gold horizontal watch, the name,
Roger Haselwood
, they were both second-hand watches; it was about nine o'clock in the morning; the name that he gave me was
Thomas Rosewell
; he paid me with the bill of exchange that I produced a little while ago; I gave him thirty-two pounds one shilling in change; I gave him two bank notes, one of twenty pounds, and the other of fifteen pounds; there was a man with him, but I don't know who that man was: he said he came to me because I had used him well in a watch he bought some time ago, that he had an order from a friend who desired him to buy two very good gold watches, one a gold repeating watch; he further desired that I would change them, in case his friend did not approve of them; when he had agreed so far, he said he had not ready money, he gave me that bill, and desired I would be satisfied that it was good before I took it; and when I was so satisfied, that I would wait upon him at Staple's Inn coffee-house at eleven as near as I could that day; he desired I would be particular to eleven o'clock, because he had other business to do; I took the bill to Sir
William Leman
's to enquire whether it was good, I shewed it to a gentleman who is one of the partners, and upon looking over it, I found it was accepted, payable at the Bank; he told me it was very good, but I was not satisfied, I went to the Bank; the first clerk in the accomptant's-office told me the bill was very good, but he would go and enquire at the office where those bills were paid; he went and enquired, and told me it was just as good as a bank note, and I might have cash for it if I wanted it; I then went home and packed up the goods as he had ordered me; he desired me to pack them separate in two different boxes, and when I had so done, I took them to Staple's Inn coffee-house; he was not there, but before I had sat down, he came in; I took the boxes out of my pocket, and gave them to him, and I gave him the two bank notes; the two bank notes over balanced the bill, and he gave me the difference in money.
Did you know this young man? - No; only from his having been a customer before; he had been several times at my shop before.
Was the other prisoner at the coffee-house at the time? - No, he was not.

JOHN RIDGEWAY
sworn.

I am servant to the last witness; I work in his shop; I remember both the prisoners coming to my master's shop; they came in a coach; the youngest came out of the coach first, and then called the other in; they both came into the shop upon Tuesday last, about half an hour after eight in the morning.

JANE WHEELER
sworn.

I am the wife of
Robert Wheeler
; I live in Great Wild-street, I let a room upon the first floor forwards to the two prisoners.

Had either of the prisoners the key of your street door? - Yes; the father had; I cannot recollect the night; it was about a week, I believe, before this happened; they always came in at good hours; I never knew them out, except they were out that night; he asked me as a favour to lend him the key, as he was going out, that possibly he might be in by eleven o'clock, but as he was not certain as to that, he would not disturb me.
When was this? - About a week before that time.
Prisoner. I made an agreement when I took the room to have the key of the door.

ELIZABETH EDWARDS
sworn.
I lodge in Mr. Wheeler's house.
Do you recollect the prisoners going out upon Sunday last? - No; upon Monday evening I saw them go out at about seven in the evening.

Do you recollect when they returned? - No, I went to bed at twelve, they were not returned then; I heard them come home about six in the morning; I did not see them, I only heard them; I heard the son rap at the door, the father followed him, and had words with him because he made a noise.
What part of the house do you sleep in? - The ground floor forwards.
Did you hear them come into the house? - I heard them come in up the passage.
Who opened the door to them? - Some child, I cannot say who.
Did they stay in the house? - They staid in their own room about an hour; then I saw them go out together at about seven o'clock.

GEORGE ROWNEY
's DEFENCE.

My son went out in the morning, he brought a parcel home, which, he said, he found as he came along among some bricks just by King-street, where there were some buildings; I opened it, and saw there were some papers; I threw them by in my window carelesly; I never saw him till the next morning.

THOMAS ROWNEY
's DEFENCE.

I found them all wrapped up in a parcel as I was coming from Billingsgate, at the corner of King-street; I brought them home, and took out these three notes, and carried one of them to Mr. Wightwick's.

To JEALOUS. Did you observe any blood upon either of the prisoners? - The son had one of his fingers fresh cut, and there is blood upon the notes; he had something wrapped round his finger when he came into the room.
To WIGHTWICK. Did you observe that, Mr. Wightwick? - There was something about his finger; he attempted to open the watches, and could not, and desired me to do it for him.

GEORGE ROWNEY
. I have a witness to prove more particularly which way this young man came by the things, she was along with him when he found them; my attorney, Mr. Topping, was to move the court in order to put off the trial, but he has not done it.

BOTH
GUILTY .
Death .

Tried by the London Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

493, 494.
JOHN KITCHEN
and
CHARLOTTE MUNFORD
were indicted for
stealing seven guineas and two shillings in money numbered , the property of
James Davis
, April 20th .

The prosecutor and the prisoners were drinking in a public house together; after which they put the prosecutor into a dust-cart, but he was so exceedingly intoxicated that he did not know how he got out of the cart, nor how he lost his money.

BOTH
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the London Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

495.
ELIZABETH WHITES
was indicted, that a certain man, whose name to the Jurors is yet unknown, and
ELIZABETH
the wife of
WILLIAM WHITES
,
not having the fear of God before her eyes, but being moved and seduced by the instigation of the devil, upon
Elizabeth Cobb
, spinster , violently and feloniously did make an assault, and that the said man, her the said
Elizabeth Cobb
, against her will, did ravish and carnally know, and that the prisoner
Elizabeth Whites
was present aiding, abetting, comforting, assisting, and maintaining the said man the said felony to do and commit , April 14th .
NOT GUILTY .

496.
JOHN JENKINS
was indicted for
stealing a copper tea-kettle, value ten pence, a copper coffee-pot, value six pence, a copper quart pot, value four pence , the property of
Patrick Fenning
, April 21st .

PATRICK FENNING
sworn.

I am a labourer in the king's Victualling-yard; I lost the things mentioned in the indictment from my house at Saltpetre-bank
; I saw them there on the Friday night, I missed them on Sunday morning the 21st of April.

THOMAS LEE
sworn.
I am servant to Mr. Akerman; on Sunday the 21st of April I stopped the prisoner with these things upon him (producing the things mentioned in the indictment) I delivered them over to the constable.
- WOODFIELD sworn.
I am a constable; I had these things delivered to me.
Prosecutor. These are mine.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I found them tied up in a blanket in the Borough about seven o'clock on Sunday morning.
GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

497.
JOHN COLVIL
was indicted for
stealing a leather pocket book, value four shillings , the property of
William Johnson
, May 20th .
The Prosecutor could not identify the book, nor was he certain that any book had been stole from him.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

498.
MARY SMITH
was indicted for
stealing two cotton window curtains, value one shilling , the property of
Sebastian Luna
, April 29th .

SEBASTIAN LUNA
sworn.

I keep a public house at Billingsgate
; my wife let the prisoner in to sleep in the bed of a person that is up early; she came down and desired to be served with some gin; I was going to serve her; my wife went up to see if every thing was safe; and then the prisoner slipped away without the gin; I suspected all was not right, and went and called her back, then she went to the end of the tap-room, and laid down the curtains; they were taken from between the bed and sacking where she lay.
The prisoner in her defence called two witnesses, who gave her a good character.
GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

499.
JAMES PRICE
was indicted for
stealing a silk handkerchief, value ten pence , the property of
Benjamin Stevenson
, May 23d .

BENJAMIN STEVENSON
. sworn.

On Thursday I was in the procession with the charity children in Newgate-street
; I felt something at my pocket-book; I turned about and saw the prisoner; I missed my handkerchief; he ran away; I pursued him and took him, and found the handkerchief stuffed in an apron he had on.
PRISONER's DEFENCE.
I found the handkerchief on the ground.
GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

500.
THOMAS COPPERTWHAITE
was indicted for
having in his possession a bill of exchange directed to
John Pollard
and William Preston, New Basinghall-street, for the payment of 43 l. to the order of
Thomas Bradley
, two months after date, that he unlawfully and falsely did pretend to
Thomas Broughton
that the said
John Pollard
was a good man, and was in partnership with a house in Bartholomew-lane, and by that false pretence obtained several quantities of goods, and 29 l. 15 s. 6 d. in money, against the statute, &c.

THOMAS BROUGHTON
sworn.

I received from the defendant a note drawn in the same manner for 25 l. which note I passed off, and that note was paid; afterwards the defendant brought me this note, and when I looked at the note, he said it is upon the same person as the last note; it is drawn upon a good person, and that you know. I said if it is drawn upon Mr. Pollard, who is in partnership with the house in Bartholomew-lane; but this is not Bartholomew-lane, it is Basinghall-street. Copperthwaite said, It is that Mr. Pollard, and though the house is in Bartholomew-lane, he lives in Basinghall-street, and you know that to be as good a house as any in London. I delivered him the goods he wanted: four gallons of brandy shrub, seventeen bottles, five gallons of rum, five gallons of brandy, and two casks.

THOMAS DODSON
sworn.

I came here to inform the court that that note was not upon the house of
Richard Holden
and company, and that that note never made its appearance at our shop; I am clerk there, and accept all the bills that are drawn upon the house; we never had any bills drawn from such place and by such names; nor never had any connexion with such people.
DEFENCE.

I never mentioned Pollard's name at all. The first bill which I had, which was in August, for 26 l. 10 s. I left with Mr. Broughton; here is an evidence in court that left it with him; I never offered him the 43 l. bill in payment; I offered him a draft upon Sir
William Leman
for 23 l. When Mr. Broughton came in with the bill, he and I were at Old Will's Coffee-house together, we talked the matter over in our conversation; he promised that he would take half cash, in the course of a week or ten days, if I would give him the remainder. I sent him up 22 l. to Mr. Leveridge, he was to go to pay a note; he did not come upon the Saturday night, and then the advertisement came in. When he found I could not get the money, he said he would prevent my joining the regiment, as he knew I was an officer in the militia.
GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

rs.p:
Archibald Girdwood
and
Thomas Jones , otherwise Evans
, formerly capitally convicted, but upon whom judgment had been respited till the opinions of the Judges could be taken upon a point of law arising in their respective cases, were set to the bar, when Mr. Justice ASTON informed them, that the Judges were unanimously of opinion that their conviction was strictly legal, and they accordingly received sentence of death.
